thread.title: Ruling to Let Migrants Travel Around Greece, Officials Say

author: Nektaria Stamouli
title: Ruling to Let Migrants Travel Around Greece, Officials Say
text:
3 COMMENTS ATHENS—A Greek court ruled that migrants arriving on Aegean islands near Turkey should be allowed to travel freely around the country, officials said, a decision that could alleviate dire conditions on the islands , but might derail a pact between the European Union and Turkey to keep a lid on arrivals.
Greece’s highest administrative court ruled Wednesday that there are no “serious or overriding reasons of public interest” to justify the government’s prohibition on migrants’ leaving the islands and traveling to the Greek mainland, according to Greek officials. The ruling wasn’t immediately made public.
Under the terms of the EU-Turkey deal , migrants and refugees arriving from Turkey must remain in detention centers on the Greek islands of Lesbos, Chios, Samos, Leros, Kos and Rhodes until their asylum applications are reviewed.
But the backlog of applicants and the slow-moving Greek bureaucracy have left thousands of people trapped in overcrowded centers for months or longer. The court ruling is effective immediately but isn’t retroactive, so it won’t apply to the people already on the islands, only to new arrivals.
Greek authorities have been reluctant to move large numbers of migrants to the mainland as they fear this would encourage more migrants. Around 16,000 migrants and refugees are currently languishing in reception centers on the Greek islands, nearly triple the centers’ capacity. The overcrowding has left many sleeping outside, while the dire conditions have left many exposed to disease and violence.
Aid groups say Greek officials have allowed the conditions to deteriorate to create a deterrent to other would-be migrants. Greek officials say they are trying to deal with the backlog of applications swiftly.
The court ruled on the Greek asylum service’s decision in May 2016 restricting migrants to the islands after a migrant aid group filed a complaint seeking its revocation.
Migrants on the island of Samos in November. Photo: Eirini Vourloumis for The Wall Street Journal The Greek Migration Ministry declined immediate comment on the ruling, but said a provision regulating the issue is included in upcoming legislation. While the Greek government cannot appeal the ruling, senior Greek officials say the asylum service plans to issue new orders designed to maintain the current regime.
The court ruling could endanger the EU-Turkey deal because that agreement requires Greek authorities to review migrants’ asylum applications at the point at which they enter the country. If their asylum application is rejected, they can be returned to Turkey or their country of origin. It isn’t clear whether Turkey would accept people back if they don’t come from the islands or whether European officials would allow Greece to move migrants to the mainland.
Meanwhile, the ministry said it would submit in the coming days new legislation aimed at accelerating the process of reviewing asylum requests.
The number of migrants arriving in Greece has increased in recent weeks as the weather conditions are starting to improve and as tensions between Greece and neighboring Turkey rise. Around 2,500 people landed on the Greek islands in March, about 1,000 more than in the same period last year, according to the Migration Ministry’s figures. Around 120 people have arrived a day on average in April so far.
Greek authorities are also concerned about the significant rise in arrivals from across the Greek-Turkish northeastern land border. According to police data, nearly 1,700 people were detained for illegal entry into the country after crossing the Evros River last month, compared with 262 people in March 2017.
